Braca a** , A.M. Raspolli Galletti a, G. Sbrana a, M. Lami b, M. Marchionna b a Dipartimento di &mica e Chimica Industriale, Universitci di Piss, via Risorgimento 35, I-56126 Piss, Italy b SNAMPROGElTl S.p.A., Research Division, Via Maritano 26, I-20097 San Donato Milanese, Italy Received 19 May 1994; accepted 8 September 1994 Abstract The hydrogenolysis of formic esters to methanol, as the second step of the low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas, has been studied using rhenium catalysts. henium blackscontaining reduced Re( 0) species produced n situstarting from soluble rhenium precursors like Rez07 or Rez( CO) ,,, are active and generally very selective (99%) in the hydrogenation of the formyl group to methanol. Unfortunately this catalyst suffers from CO poisoning: however, the poisoning is reversible and the catalytic activity can be restored by treatment with pure hydrogen. Rhenium catalysts supported on oxides generally are less active and selective: the acid or basic centres of the support, which strongly interact with the oxophilic rhenium cations, make difficult the generation of the active Re( 0) species and on other hand promote the decarboxylation of the formic ester. Keywords: CO; Formic esters; Hydrogenation; Poisoning; Rhenium 1. Introduction Several process alternatives have been pro- posed for converting CO/H2 to methanol at milder conditions with respect to the current copper-cat- alyzed process in order to improve the thermo- dynamic efficiency of the process. Among these alternatives one of the most notable is the synthe- sis of methanol via an alkyl formate, generally methyl formate [ 1 ] : CH,OH + CO + HCOOCH3 (1) HCOOCH, + Hz + 2CH30H (2) CO + 2H2 + CH30H (3) * Corresponding author. Methanol is first carbonylated to methyl for- mate and the subsequent hydrogenolysis results in the gain of a methanol molecule over the total reaction (Eqs. l-3). While the carbonylation step is commercially available, the hydrogenolysis, in order to be eco- nomically advantageous, must be carried out using a hydrogen feed containing the CO not con- verted in the carbonylation stage; as a conse- quence, the hydrogenolysis catalyst must be insensitive to CO poisoning [ 11. Furthermore the same catalyst should be able to depress undesired reactions such as decarbonylation and decarbox- ylations (Eqs. 4-7) ; reaction (7) follows an inter- mediate hydrolysis step occurring when water is present: 1381-l 169/95/$09.50 0 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. By using R@OT as precursor, under high hydrogen pressure and at temperatures rang- ing from 120 to 220, a heterogeneous hydro- genation catalyst indicated as henium blackis obtained, able also to hydrogenate esters and a lot of carboxylic acids to alcohols but not formic acid to methanol [ 51. Supported Re catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation of the support with slightly warm solutions of ammonium perrhenate and successive drying at 250 for 8 h. The determination of rhenium content in the various supported catalysts was carried out spec- trophotometrically according to literature proce- dure [ 171. The hydrogenolysis reactions were carried out in a 190 ml Hastelloy C rocking autoclave filled with a glass vial and heated in an oil bath and equipped with devices for removal of liquid and gas samples during the runs. 2.3. The infrared cell was interfaced to a gas manifold to maintain the recovered catalyst under argon. 3. Results and discussion 3. I. Hydrogenolysis of methyl for-mate with soluble rhenium precursors The most utilized soluble rhenium precursors reported in the literature are the Re(VII) oxide, Re207, and the Re( 0) carbonyl Re,( CO) iO. Hydrogenolysis runs on methyl formate, car- ried out with Re,O, reduced in situ to e black at 200 and 10 MPa of hydrogen, displayed good selectivity to methanol (up to 99%)) being very limited the decomposition of the formic moiety to CO or CO2 (run 1, Table 1). The recycled henium blackcatalyst did not lose significantly activity and selectivity in suc- cessive hydrogenolysis cycles (Table 1, run 2). The hydrogenolysis of methyl formate took place very rapidly also under milder temperature conditions ( 15O, but at higher pressures and rhenium concentrations) and also using THF as solvent (Table 1, run 5 and 6). In contrast, when the hydrogenolysis was car- ried out in the presence of initial CO (HZ/CO: 10) (Table 1, run 3), a marked decrease of the catalytic activity was observed. Contemporary a great part ( ~60%) of the catalyst was trans- Table 1 Hydrogenolysis of methyl formate with Re,O, formed into Re,(CO) i,-, present in solution or adsorbed on the solid catalyst. This result gave an indirect confirmation of the prevailing Re(0) nature of henium blackand prompted us to accomplish a new synthesis route of RQ( CO) i0 from Rq07 under mild conditions in the presence of CO/H, mixtures [ 191. After removal of the adsorbed ReZ( CO) 1,,, the residual solid catalyst was used in a successive hydrogenolysis cycle under pure H2 (Table 1, run 4): its activity (expressed as TN and taking into account the loss of soluble Re) and selectivity toward MeOH were completely restored. This indicates that henium blackcan be regenerated under pure HZ. IR spectrum of the solid catalyst recovered from run 4 indicates the complete absence of carbonyl species. To better clarify the phenomenon of CO- induced catalyst inhibition, the hydrogenolysis of methyl formate was also investigated starting from homogeneous rhenium metal carbonyl com- plexes. Catalysts originated from Re,( CO) i0 were less active both in pure methyl formate and in THF with respect to the corresponding catalysts obtained from Re,O, working under analogous conditions (compare runs 7-8, Table 2 with runs 5-6, Table 1) . The selectivity to methanol was always > 95% being CH, and CO2 the only by-products; no decarbonylation reaction of methyl formate was noticed. Hydrogenolysis of formic esters with supported heterogeneous rhenium catalysts In order to diminish rhenium concentration and attain a better dispersion of metal, heterogeneous catalysts, prepared by wet impregnation of differ- ent supports with ammonium perrhenate, were prepared and tested after a preactivation with 10 MPa of hydrogen at 200 in n-hexane. Acid, neutral and basic supports were used. When Re/SiO:, was used in the hydrogenolysis of methyl formate, the activity and selectivity toward MeOH appeared reduced with respect to catalysts prepared from homogeneous precursors (compare run 12, Table 3 with run 1, Table 1) and a significant formation of CO2 and methane was observed. The formation of Re( 0) carbonyl species should indicate the presence of metal Re (0) in the preactivated catalyst and of weak interactions between rhenium and Si02 which facilitate its reduction [ 241. The lower catalytic activity of the supported catalyst with respect to henium black is probably related to residual not fully reduced rhenium species, dissolved into bulk SiO, [ 251. The residual solid catalyst, used in a successive recycle under pure HZ, restored again nearly com- pletely its activity and selectivity (run 15, Table 3). The acid -A&O3 was also used as support for rhenium catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of methyl formate. The catalyst was very little active in this reaction whereas promoted an extensive ester decomposition (decarbonylation and decarbox- ylation), favoured by the acid character of the support (Table 3, run 16). These negative performances point out once again the relevance of reducing Re completely: the reduction of rhenium on 3/-A1203 is in fact reported to be more difficult with respect to Re/ SiO:, due to the oxophilic nature of the rhenium cations which are strongly bonded to the support oxide surface [ 26,271. These strong metal support interactions (SMSI) prevent the reduction step [ 28,291, causing a significant decrease of the cat- alytic activity of the hydrogenolysis reaction. General conclusions The present work shows that heterogeneous dis- persed rhenium catalysts, i.e. Re(0) henium black is an active (TN: 10 g MeOH/ (g Re X h) and selective (selectivity > 99%) catalyst for the hydrogenation of the HCO group to methanol under not too drastic conditions (T: 150-2OO, P: 10-15 MPa). Unfortunately, the active metal rhenium is poi- soned, albeit in a reversible manner, by CO with formation of rhenium cat-bony1 species: the car- bonylation may proceed up to the formation of soluble Re,( CO) 10. The henium blackupon recycle maintains unchanged its catalytic activity and after poison- ing by CO can be restored by treatment at high temperature (200) with pure H,. The formation of oxidized rhenium(I) species corresponds to the occurrence of less active cata- lysts, both in the homogeneous (species [Re (CO), (OHh ad [Re2 (CO), (OW,-, (OH),] - ) , and in the heterogeneous phase ( spe- cies [Re (CO),] [OM*],_, [HOM*], (x=0- 3;M*=Al,Mg,). Thus, only neutral and almost inert matrices can be proposed as supports for the rhenium catalysts to be used in the hydrogenation of the formyl moiety of the formic esters without causing their decarboxylation to CO2 and CH,. The hydrogenolysis of formic esters to methanol, as the second step of the low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas, has been studied using rhenium catalysts. ‘Rhenium blacks’ containing reduced Re(0) species produced ‘in situ’ starting from soluble rhenium precursors like Re2O7 or Re2(CO)10 are active and generally very selective (99%) in the hydrogenation of the formyl group to methanol. Unfortunately this catalyst suffers from CO poisoning: however, the poisoning is reversible and the catalytic activity can be restored by treatment with pure hydrogen. Rhenium catalysts supported on oxides generally are less active and selective: the acid or basic centres of the support, which strongly interact with the oxophilic rhenium cations, make difficult the generation of the active Re(0) species and on other hand promote the decarboxylation of the formic ester.
